column1: # Opcode Column in the Instruction Summary Table (Instructions without VEX Prefix), Intel Vol2 Table 3-1

column4: Meaning
Indicates the use of 66/F2/F3 prefixes (beyond those already part of the instructions opcode) are not allowed with the instruction
Indicates the use of F2/F3 prefixes (beyond those already part of the instructions opcode) are not allowed with the instruction.
Indicates the use of a REX prefix that affects operand size or instruction semantics
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand.
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand.
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand.
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand.
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand.
The ModR/M byte of the instruction uses only the r/m operand.
Indicates that the ModR/M byte of the instruction contains a register operand and an r/m operand.
A 1-byte value following the opcode to specify a code offset and/or new value for the code segment register.
A 2-byte value following the opcode to specify a code offset and/or new value for the code segment register.
A 4-byte value following the opcode to specify a code offset and/or new value for the code segment register.
A 6-byte value following the opcode to specify a code offset and/or new value for the code segment register.
A 8-byte value following the opcode to specify a code offset and/or new value for the code segment register.
A 10-byte value following the opcode to specify a code offset and/or new value for the code segment register.
A 1-byte immediate operand to the instruction that follows the opcode or ModR/M bytes or scale-indexing bytes.
A 2-byte immediate operand to the instruction that follows the opcode or ModR/M bytes or scale-indexing bytes.
A 4-byte immediate operand to the instruction that follows the opcode or ModR/M bytes or scale-indexing bytes.
A 8-byte immediate operand to the instruction that follows the opcode or ModR/M bytes or scale-indexing bytes.
Not encodable
A number used in floating-point instructions when one of the operands is ST(i) from the FPU register stack.

column3: REX prefixes that promote legacy instructions to 64-bit behavior are not listed explicitly in the opcode column.
The register field digit 0 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The register field digit 1 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The register field digit 2 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The register field digit 3 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The register field digit 4 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The register field digit 5 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The register field digit 6 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The register field digit 7 provides an extension to the instruction's opcode
The opcode determines if the operand is a signed value. All words and doublewords and quadwords are given with the low-order byte first.
The opcode determines if the operand is a signed value. All words and doublewords and quadwords are given with the low-order byte first.
The opcode determines if the operand is a signed value. All words and doublewords and quadwords are given with the low-order byte first.
The opcode determines if the operand is a signed value. All words and doublewords and quadwords are given with the low-order byte first.
The number i (which can range from 0 to 7) is added to the hexadecimal byte given at the left of the plus sign to form a single opcode byte.

For an 8-bit register indicates: (a) In non-64-bit mode, a register code is arithmetically added to the value of the opcode byte. (b) In 64-bit mode, the four bit field of REX.b and opcode[2:0] field encodes the register operand of the instruction

For a 16-bit register indicates: (a) In non-64-bit mode, a register code is arithmetically added to the value of the opcode byte. (b) In 64-bit mode, the four bit field of REX.b and opcode[2:0] field encodes the register operand of the instruction

For a 32-bit register indicates: (a) In non-64-bit mode, a register code is arithmetically added to the value of the opcode byte. (b) In 64-bit mode, the four bit field of REX.b and opcode[2:0] field encodes the register operand of the instruction
For a 64-bit register, indicates the four bit field of REX.b and opcode[2:0] field encodes the register operand of the instruction
